displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that. Patient: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page. Doctor: Comfortable with that? Patient: I am. Doctor: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?

Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA.

Patient: I can live with it if I can do the infusion stuff up there. Doctor: Okay. That's a possibility. However, as anything else, we actually have a study. Half the group gets regular chemo, which is IV. The other group gets a pill chemo which is oral. I can't tell you which one you are. And of course, we need you to commit so that if you say there's no freakin way I'm gonna get chemo down here then don't do the trial, but it's a fifty-fifty Family Member: You don't want to come down here xxx do you? Patient: How often do I have to be here? Doctor: Well, chemo is once every three weeks. So if you're good, don't quote me because I botched up a thousand things today in terms of the schedule, which is why I keep my mouth shut half the time. But standard chemo is once every three weeks. Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad. Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. And the pill you take, there's a funky schedule but normally it's like, twice a day. But not every day. And there's a set schedule. You don't have to be here every day for that. But I think the follow up there is once every four weeks if I'm not wrong. Family Member: The pill isn't in the container? He has to come down here? Doctor: Well, we give it to you. But it's a funky formulation where, because you know, we do an oral formulation of the chemo is a challenge. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So this is like, there's a loading dose and then you have a little bit of another dose. So it's like, it's a pharma-pharmaco kinetics dream, who thought about it, which is not like a doctor dream, which is like, “just give me the pill in my pocket once a day.” I think eventually they're going to do that. But there is a funky schedule to it. None of which you have to be here, you know, the entire time. But I think in the first few- oh gosh, the first few days I think that you're here maybe for the first week every day. So, but I'll get the schedule right, but once you get on a flow, you're not here every day. Not even close. So it’s either once every three weeks, or once every four weeks. Patient: I can do it because obviously the Xtandi has run its course.

Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Um, we have scans that are sort of trending worse but nothing definitively worse --- by new other than the adrenal thing, and that is hedging. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And then, you have your PSA which is thirteen down to four point nine at your lowest, and back up to ten. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Yes. He’s gotten it. Doctor: Did you get a flu shot this year? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You got it in September, October, November? Family Member: September. Yes. Patient: September. Doctor: Okay. I’m going to just let her know the camera may have done something. Healthcare Professional: The paper towel looks like. Doctor: You said it’s okay? Okay. How are you? Patient: Hum, all right, except my neck hurts where that rod is. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, so you scored your pain a six. Was that for that pain or to the abdomen? Patient: Oh, that’s when, huh, they gave me the needle. I told her. Doctor: Okay. Good. But six isn’t your neck or-?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs)

Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there. Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws.

Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease-

Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. Healthcare Professional: He had a Buick Encore; that’s a nice car, too. Family Member: Yeah, that was a beautiful car. Doctor: Yeah, so now he’s. So she was sort of joking that if you get any girls’ phone calls, that’s the reason he’s getting them, not - Family Member: Oh my god! Patient: Yeah, “Mom, can I borrow your car?” Doctor: Yeah, exactly. Yeah, he definitely took it for a spin and - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh gosh! That’s funny! Patient: So what does N___ drive? Doctor: He drives a Cadillac.

Patient: But it seemed like I, would have, I was degenerating pretty quickly for you know? For all the bone scans I’ve had… Doctor: Yeah. Yes. Patient: Somebody would have seen that somewhere. Doctor: No. I think it’s just crappy cancer not controlled. You know? Patient: And Uh. Yeah. Doctor: There’s, there’s the uh oh this is really going to be in trouble. We got that fixed. But it’s the bigger picture. Patient: You know uh you know and I feel I actually am you know doc I’m not running today but I’m getting around better. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I’ve, I’ve seen the, you know the steady increase. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Uh, you know, little dips on certain days. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation? Doctor: Yeah, so when you see Dr. B____, so that’s another Dr. B, you’re going to listen about what can or can’t you do, why is it once a month, what are your obligations. What are the potential side effects and how does he want to see you and he might need blood work kind of not on day of because there’s a half-life to the medicine as in if he knows the week before your counts are good to go then he can order it and when you show up it’s here and you get it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If he orders it and you show up and uh-oh you can’t get it, there’s, we’re in trouble. Patient: Right, Okay. Doctor: That’s fifteen thousand you might have to just flush down the toilet because you can’t save it for the next week because it starts to decay and you can’t give it to somebody else so. Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me see. Yeah Patient: Yeah… Doctor: it looks pretty good. Pretty smooth. Patient: Yeah and it – this is not from my shaving. I ran into the garage door because I I Doctor: Ohh. Patient: didn’t allow it to get high enough. I bent my head - Doctor: Because you were in a rush. Patient: I was in a rush to get out. (Laughs) Doctor: Stop that! Alright sit tight here. Let me go get her. Patient: Okay. Doctor: She just wants to wave and kick you out. Patient: Okay. Thank you very much.
